questions.text: A 48 year male presented with a history of fever with loss of weight and appetite since the last 3 weeks. There are no other localizing symptoms for fever. He underwent TAVR procedure for severe symptomatic aortic stenosis 8 months ago. On examination, pallor + grade 2 clubbing +. On auscultation, a new regurgitant murmur is heard in the aortic area. What is the possible causative organism for this disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS) Prosthetic valve endocarditis ( the most common valve involved is aortic valve) Within 2 months of surgery, coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS) After 2 months of surgery, coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS) Hence other options are wrong.

Highyeild:

Native valve endocarditis Prosthetic valve endocarditis Endocarditis in injection drug users Streptococci Staph. aureus CoNS staph. aureus Rt. sided- Staph aureus Lt. sided- Enterococci

questions.text: A 36 year old female patient with a history of repeated attacks of joint pain and fever in her childhood, presents with dyspnea for 6 months associated with hemoptysis. He had episodes of awakening at night associated with profuse sweating, which was relieved by sitting upright with his legs hanging from the bed. On auscultation, there are bibasal crepitations, and a characteristic murmur is heard. What is the correct description of this murmur?

options.label: A
options.text: Harsh ejection systolic crescendo decrescendo murmur

options.label: B
options.text: Mid diastolic rumbling murmur with presystolic accentuation

options.label: D
options.text: Holosystolic murmur with radiation to left axilla

questions.correct_answer: B. Mid diastolic rumbling murmur with presystolic accentuation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mid diastolic rumbling murmur with presystolic accentuation This patient, with a history suggestive of repeated episodes of rheumatic fever (joint pains with fever) along with dyspnea and hemoptysis with episodes suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (awakening at night associated with profuse sweating, which was relieved on sitting upright with his legs hanging from the bed), points to a clinical picture of mitral stenosis. The murmur of mitral stenosis is mid diastolic rumbling murmur with presystolic accentuation (due to atrial contraction just before systole).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : This is the classical murmur of aortic stenosis Option C : This is the classical murmur of aortic regurgitation Option D : This is the classical murmur of mitral regurgitation

questions.text: A 22 year old female presents to you with primary amenorrhea. She has a short stature with a webbed neck and Tanner 2 Breasts. On auscultation, you find an ejection click. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bicuspid aortic valve In this patient with typical findings suggestive of Turner’s syndrome , an ejection systolic click is likely due to a bicuspid aortic valve.

Highyeild:

Bicuspid aortic valve is found in approximately 2% of the population and shows a strong association with Turner’s syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis, but is associated with early onset of AS.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : AS may be associated with an ejection click but an ejection systolic murmur will also be heard Option C : Pulmonary stenosis is associated with Noonan’s syndrome , the so called “male Turner’s syndrome” Option D : PDA produces a continuous murmur without any click.

questions.text: A 23 year old male had an attack of palpitations during his qualifying football match. He has a history of an uncle who died an unexplained death at a young age. A bisferiens type of pulse is found on examination. What is the murmur expected on auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both b and c This clinical picture of sudden onset palpitations in an athlete, with family history of sudden cardiac death is suggestive of HOCM .

Highyeild:

It is characterized by myofiber disarray resulting in hypertrophy of the heart, including the septum and the LV outflow tract. This leads to dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO), causing an ejection systolic murmur . The high velocity jet produced by the aforementioned obstruction pulls the anterior mitral leaflet towards the septum because of Bernoulli’s phenomenon, causing mitral regurgitation . Hence both an ejection systolic and a holosystolic murmur will be heard on auscultation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Early diastolic decrescendo murmur is heard in aortic regurgitation which is not seen in HOCM

questions.text: A known case of MS complains of increasing dyspnea with exertion for the past 4 months. On examination, the vitals are stable, chest is clear on auscultation and a palpable P2 is found on the precordium. You suspect a complication of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following is true about your probable diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of primary pulmonary hypertension

options.label: B
options.text: It belongs to WHO Group I

options.label: C
options.text: A loud diastolic decrescendo murmur may be heard in the pulmonary area

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary hypertension confers a better prognosis

questions.correct_answer: C. A loud diastolic decrescendo murmur may be heard in the pulmonary area
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A loud diastolic decrescendo murmur may be heard in the pulmonary area In the context of MS, increasing exertional dyspnea along with a palpable P2 (diastolic shock) and a clear chest raise a strong suspicion of pulmonary hypertension. In severe pulmonary hypertension seen in long standing MS, the pulmonary valve ring dilates leading to pulmonary regurgitation, and a consequent early diastolic decrescendo murmur known as Graham Steele murmur .

Highyeild:

This is a case of WHO Group 2 PHTN Type 1 : Pulmonary arterial hypertension Type 2: Pulmonary venous hypertension due to left heart disease Type 3: Pulmonary venous hypertension due to lung disease Type 4 : Pulmonary hypertension due to chronic thromboembolic disease Type 5 : Multifactorial

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Since there is an identifiable etiologic factor, this is a case of secondary pulmonary hypertension Option B : This is a case of WHO Group 2 PHTN Type 1 : Pulmonary arterial hypertension Type 2: Pulmonary venous hypertension due to left heart disease Type 3: Pulmonary venous hypertension due to lung disease Type 4 : Pulmonary hypertension due to chronic thromboembolic disease Type 5 : Multifactorial Option D : Development of PHTN confers a poor prognosis in MS

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with a history of weight loss, fever and exertional dyspnea for the past 3 months. There is no past history suggestive of rheumatic fever. On examination, her vitals are stable, but pulse volume is low. On auscultation, a mid diastolic rumbling murmur is heard which changes in character with change in position. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left atrial myxoma This patient shows a relatively short history of exertional dyspnea with constitutional signs. Given the examination findings, the most common diagnosis would be rheumatic MS, as most patients of rheumatic MS do not have a clear cut history of RF. However, the variation of the murmur with position is an important characteristic which clinches the diagnosis to a left atrial myxoma . It is a myxoid tumor most commonly found in the LA which produces ball valve type obstruction and consequent murmur which mimics MS. A tumor plop may also be heard, which is a low pitched diastolic sound.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Congenital MS presents earlier, without constitutional signs and without any positional variation of murmur Option C : Severe AR can produce a mid diastolic murmur at the apex, known as Austin Flint murmur. However, this does not show any positional variation or presystolic accentuation. Moreover, the pulse volume will be high Option D : As stated above, positional variation rules out rheumatic MS and virtually clinches diagnosis to myxoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old female had undergone a routine pre job examination, and on auscultation was found to have a mid systolic click followed by a late systolic crescendo decrescendo murmur best heard in the mitral area. Which of the following statements are true about the condition this patient has?

options.label: B
options.text: It may occur as a sequelae of rheumatic fever

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above An apparently normal patient with a mid systolic click and a late systolic murmur is likely to be a case of mitral valve prolapse. It commonly affects females between 15-30 years of age. It is due to myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. Patients are commonly asymptomatic (option a) , but may present with palpitations. It is associated with disorders of connective tissue like EDS, Marfan’s (option c) -It also may be a sequelae of rheumatic fever (option b) . Diagnosis is established by echocardiography, and treatment with valve repair is indicated if the patient is symptomatic with severe

questions.text: A 64 year old man presents with palpitations and throbbing of his hands and feet for 6 months. On examination, the vitals are stable, but he has a wide pulse pressure. Systemic examination shows positive Hill’s sign. On auscultation, a grade 3 diastolic decrescendo murmur is heard in the left 3rd ICS parasternally. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AR This patient presents with a classical clinical picture for aortic regurgitation . The initial presentation is usually with palpitations sometimes with angina. As the disease progresses patients may land up in heart failure, with dyspnea on exertion being the prime complaint. The hallmark is diastolic runoff of blood into the ventricle from the aorta, leading to the classically described murmur and a widened pulse pressure. A number of peripheral signs are seen because of the widened pulse pressure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Classical murmur is ejection systolic, presents with syncope Option C : Classical murmur is mid diastolic, presents with exertional dyspnea Option D : Classical murmur is holosystolic, wide pulse pressure may be seen but peripheral signs are absent.

questions.text: A 47 year old female presents with exertional dyspnea for the past 9 months, exacerbated by lying down. She also complains of occasional palpitations. On examination, here vitals are stable. Auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard in the mitral area at the height of expiration. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MR This patient presents with a classical clinical picture of MR. Patients usually present with dyspnea secondary to overflow of blood into the pulmonary circuit by virtue of regurgitation. Orthopnea and palpitations may also be present. Examination reveals the classical holosystolic murmur of MR, with radiation to the left axilla/inferior angle of scapula in most cases due to involvement of anterior leaflet.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Classical murmur is ejection systolic, presents with syncope Option B : Classical murmur is early diastolic decrescendo, presents with palpitations Option C : Classical murmur is mid diastolic, presents with exertional dyspnea with or without hemoptysis

questions.text: In a 62 year old patient presenting with exertional dyspnea and chest pain, you find an ejection systolic murmur of grade 3 on auscultation, best heard in the aortic area. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to increase the intensity of the murmur?

options.label: A
options.text: Auscultation at the height of inspiration

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rapid squatting An old patient with chest pain and exertional dyspnea with the given characteristic murmur in aortic area is likely to have AS.

Highyeild:

Rapid squatting increases the venous return and preload, as well as afterload to some extent. Therefore, the intensity of both stenotic (eg AS) and regurgitant (eg MR) murmurs are increased.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : All right sided murmurs increase on inspiration (Carvallo’s sign) and vice versa. Therefore, this murmur should decrease on inspiration Option B : Handgrip increases the afterload, therefore increases regurgitant murmurs and decreases stenotic murmurs. Option D : Valsalva maneuver (phase 2, in which auscultation is usually done), decreases preload and hence decreases intensity of most murmurs.
